WorkItem.ClosedComment:
TypeScript actually has two sorts of "errors" - parse errors (e.g. you try to write something like "var x = 13%%231f1~;" and type errors (like the one you got). Code with type errors will still generate JS.

This is sort of the second level of "optional"-ness of the typing system.
WorkItem.Description:
I don't know if the TypeScript compiler is more of a soft-enforcer (since everything goes to Javascript).  When I compile a .ts file via the command line, I keep getting an error, but the Javascript file still gets generated.

I would assume that the .js file shouldn't be created if the compiler finds an error.  The error is a simple type-mismatch for a function argument.  I also tried putting the code into typescriptlang.com/playground just to be sure and that gave me the error as well.  

So I definitely have an error.  The question is whether or not the compilation of TypeScript should still happen if there is a compile error?
WorkItem.Summary: Javascript generated after having a compiler error.

Comments.Message: Awesome! I like that a lot.  Just wanted to be sure :P
